titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William J. and Eleanor Copeland and Rudolf Reimer land deed 1977.570
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-12-12 14:22:07 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: William J. and Eleanor Copeland and Rudolf Reimer land deed
did.abstract: Quit claim deed for property in the town of Jamaica, Queens County known as the Silas Butler property between William J. and Eleanor Copeland and Rudolf Reimer. Dated 1880.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1977.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of a single document.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: The deed is broken into two pieces and should be handled with care.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); William J. and Eleanor Copeland and Rudolf Reimer land deed, 1977.570, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023. Though this item is folded in a too-small folder, it has already ripped along the crease and thus the archivist determined it did not need to be housed flat in an oversize folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Quit claim deed for property in the town of Jamaica, Queens County known as the Silas Butler property between William J. and Eleanor Copeland and Rudolf Reimer. Dated 1880.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This item is in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
